content: {{knowledge objective |Identifiant=OIC-242-09-A |Item_parent=Hyperthyroidism |Item_parent_short=Hyperthyroidism |Rank=A |Title=Knowing the three most common etiologies of hyperthyroidism |Description=Detail |Rubric=Etiologies |Contributors=Dr Camille Buffet,Dr Magali Haissaguerre |Order=9}} The 3 most common causes of hyperthyroidism are : - Graves' disease (autoimmune), the leading cause of hyperthyroidism in young women - Toxic multinodular goitre, occurring in older subjects - Toxic adenoma, occurring in older subjects

question.title: What are the three most common causes of hyperthyroidism?
question.description: Select the correct etiology of hyperthyroidism

option_a.title: Autoimmune disorders
option_a.description: A condition where the immune system attacks the thyroid gland

option_b.title: Hormonal imbalances
option_b.description: An imbalance of thyroid hormones in the body

option_c.title: Genetic disorders
option_c.description: Inherited conditions that affect the thyroid gland

option_d.title: Autoimmune multinodular goitre
option_d.description: A condition where the immune system attacks multiple nodules in the thyroid gland
